Description.val:
The requirement for the RQ-21A Unmanned Aircraft System is defined in a Capability Development Document, dated 18 November 2008 and further defined in the Capability Production Document, dated 15 February 2013.  The RQ-21A program entered the Engineering and Manufacturing Development (EMD) phase of the acquisition process as an Acquisition Category III program on 26 July 2010. On 19 August 2014 RQ-21A was designated an Acquisition Category II program.

The RQ-21A system provides the Marine Expeditionary Force and subordinate commands (divisions and regiments) and USN Naval Special Warfare (NSW) a dedicated Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance system capable of delivering intelligence products directly to the tactical commander in real time. The RQ-21A system is capable of providing actionable intelligence and communications relay for 12-hour continuous operations per day with a short surge capability of 24-hours continuous operations for l0 days. The system has an operating radius of 50 nautical miles, further extendable through hub and spoke operations. The Air Vehicle is capable of airspeeds up to 80 nautical miles per hour with a service ceiling of 15,000 feet. The Marine Corps has procured a quantity of 21 RQ-21 systems. The Navy has procured a quantity of 10 RQ-21 systems. There are no future plans to buy more RQ-21 systems at this time, but System Component - Air Vehicles will be procured. 

An RQ-21A system consists of five air vehicles, two ground control stations, modular multi-mission plug and play payloads, one launcher, one recovery system, and support equipment. Standard payloads include a turret mounted Electro Optic/Infrared (EO/IR) camera and a communications relay package with automated identification ship capability, carried in the payload bay.

The RQ-21A system will continue to evolve and upgrade capabilities to satisfy capability shortfalls, new requirements, and reliability, maintainability, safety issues and system configuration changes. Upgraded capabilities may include Navy Command and Control integration, Extended Range, Weapons Integration, Heavy Fuel Engine, Laser Designator, Frequency Agile Communications Relay, Digital Common Data Link, new launch and recovery methods, parts durability and manufacturability, and cyclic refresh of the Electro-Optical/Infrared (EO/IR) camera.

Justification.val:
FY 2021 funds are required to retrofit USMC RQ-21A systems with EO/IR turret upgrades that include, but are not limited to: laser designator capability and optics improvements required for effective identification, perform critical extruded mast upgrade retrofits for USMC and NSW recovery systems, retrofit five NSW RQ-21 air vehicles (AV) with Unmanned Radio frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite enabling special collection in operational theaters, retrofit twelve NSW RQ-21 AV's with Visual detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload to provide wide-area imaging capability, system configuration changes and upgrades required to maintain safe flight operations and support costs related to both USMC and USN RQ-21 system retrofits.

The FY 2021 funding request was reduced by $11.371M to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

Name.@footnote: Includes engineering and logistics support required to properly prepare and execute system retrofits in support of both the USMC and NSW.
Each Turret Upgrade kit contains 5 turrets to retrofit all 5 air vehicles in a RQ-21A system.  FY 2021 base quantities and funding are for two USMC RQ-21 kits.
Mast upgrades quantities reflect upgrades per RQ-21A system.  FY2021 base quantities and funding are for three USMC RQ-21 upgrades and two NSW RQ-21 upgrades, replacing welded masts.
VTOL kit includes equipment to retrofit all 5 air vehicles in a RQ-21A system for both USMC and USN NSW systems.
Unmanned Radio Frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite for the RQ-21A enables special collection in Theaters.  FY 2021 Quantity reflects 5 RQ-21 system component - air vehicles modified with SURFR.

Visual Detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload for the RQ-21A that provides a wide-area imaging capability for the air vehicle.  FY 2021 Quantity reflects 12 RQ-21 system component - air vehicles modified with ViDAR.
Other system configuration changes includes, but is not limited to, emergent upgrades required to maintain safe flight operations.

Description.val:
RQ-21 Blackjack Correction of Deficiencies provides near and long term improvements to fielded RQ-21 systems, and focuses on correcting documented deficiencies related to safety, maintainability, and aircraft systems. These modifications and selected component changes are being accomplished by field retrofit performed by contractor artisans and organic support.  In order to meet emerging deficiencies, the airframe and integrated systems must be modified as critical corrections/changes are identified. Funds will be used to manage, prepare, process and incorporate Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and implement those changes in order to sustain and improve RQ-21 system operations. ECPs are implemented to coincide with resources and aircraft availability. These changes provide more robust performance in navigation, weapons, avionics, survivability, maneuverability, maintainability, and mission deployment of the RQ-21 platform. This modification program may be required to provide timely remedial action for any aircraft system, component or structure.

FY 2019-2023 funding will modify the current Electro Optical/Infrared camera turret to include a laser designator capability and optics improvements for USMC systems. The retrofit will modify NSW and USMC air vehicles and with the rest being upgraded through attrition.

FY 2019-2021 funding will upgrade the current welded mast recovery systems with extruded aluminum masts recovery systems which are more durable for the USMC and NSW systems. This will strengthen the recovery mast and addresses critical safety concerns. Each RQ-21 system contains one recovery system.

FY 2020 will retrofit NSW RQ-21 AV's with UHF/VHF Transponders that provide IFF capability to distinguish friendly UAS and provide safety of flight, especially against friendly counter UAS efforts in theater. 

FY 2020-2023 funding is required to retrofit NSW RQ-21 AV's with Unmanned Radio frequency Receiver (SURFR) Payload Suite enabling special collection in operational theaters.

FY 2020-2022 funding will retrofit NSW RQ-21 AV's with Visual detection and Ranging (ViDAR) payload to provide wide-area imaging capability to NSW.

FY 2021-2025 funding will support system configuration and upgrades required to maintain safe flight operations of the RQ-21A Blackjack system including USMC and NSW Communications Suites to enable multi-channel voice communications to/from the RQ-21 as if it were a manned aircraft to enable kill-chain linkage.

FY 2022-2025 funding supports the modification of the air vehicles to incorporate a Vertical Takeoff and Landing (VTOL) kit. This retrofit will allow for more expeditionary employment of the RQ-21A system, reduced capture damage and mishap rate, and will reduce the footprint of systems where the capability is employed.  Funds from FY 2022-2025 will retrofit USN NSW and USMC systems.

FY 2022-2025 funding is required to perform future payload upgrade retrofits, extended range, and communications suite upgrades that improve capability to USMC and USN NSW users.
